sponsors.marquee: Welcome from OpenCAPI. Visit our booth and opencapi.org to learn how OpenCAPI and OMI can help you build faster and more efficient memory systems.
sponsors.name: OpenCAPI Consortium
sponsors.intro: OpenCAPI Consortium The purpose of the OpenCAPI Consortium is to create an open coherent high performance bus interface based on a new bus standard called Open Coherent Accelerator Processor Interface (OpenCAPI) and develop the ecosystem that utilizes this interface. This initiative is being driven by the emerging accelerated computing and advanced memory/storage solutions that have introduced significant system bottlenecks in today’s current open bus protocols and requires a technical solution that is openly available. The member collaboration define an open bus protocol standard that starts from the microprocessor interface on up to any accelerators, memory/storage solutions, bridge chips that enable further interaction with additional protocols, and potentially others. These open bus protocol standards have been made available publicly at the consortium website.

sponsors.name: Server
sponsors.intro:
Server Experience Center

Participating Companies are XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX

In the OCP NIC 3.0 experience center, our goal is to show demonstrations covering physical, logical, and functional aspects of OCP NIC 3.0 specification. Overall, we have planned seven demonstrations. We have two demonstrations showing interface sandbox with a Small Form Factor (SFF) as well as a Tall SFF NIC product respectively. We will be showing a mechanical fit-test fixture that can be used to check a physical card's compliance with OCP NIC 3.0 specification. There will be a demonstration of connectivity and manageability features of OCP NIC 3.0 specification on a Multi-Host NIC with hosts running timing and TCP applications. We also plan to showcase Fiber channel HBA in OCP NIC 3.0 form factor and a server with 12 OCP NIC 3.0 compliant slots. Finally, we will be tying both OCP NIC 3.0 and device attestation specifications by showing the attestation of OCP NIC 3.0 compliant Ethernet NIC using Secure Protocol Data Model (SPDM), one of the attestation protocols recommended by the OCP security project.
